abstract.p: Peter Collins letter disputes David Thomson's assertion in June 11 article that The Long Goodbye is one of Robert Altman's best films (S)

block.p: David Thomson is unstinting in his praise of Robert Altman, as well he should be. ''M*A*S*H,'' ''McCabe and Mrs. Miller,'' ''Nashville'' and ''The Player'' are wonderful, enduring cinematic works of art. But when Mr. Thomson calls ''The Long Goodbye'' an ''unequivocally great'' work, judges it ''one of our great films'' and even places it above ''Nashville'' in the Altman oeuvre, he comes close to losing credibility for all his other judgments. ''The Long Goodbye'' does not transcend Raymond Chandler and Philip Marlowe (and Bogart) in ''The Big Sleep,'' as Mr. Thomson contends, but ennobles them. We can be eternally grateful for legitimate film noir masterpieces, and we can consign ''The Long Goodbye'' to the dust heap of mediocrity where it belongs.
